While probably not as directly symbolic as, say, "Grand Canyon," it definitely makes a comment about ambition and convention.Overall, this movie is not to be taken seriously. This is far from an Adam Sandler/Jim Carrey mindless comedy with plenty of sewer humor and sight gags. Unfortunately the story does have several (unnecessary) sexual overtones which detract from the movie's overall messages (although I'm sure many would argue with that). In the end, it's about ambition, disillusionment, convention and finding your place in the world. If those are themes you can identify with, Rushmore is worth your time.

Review title: A comedy with remarkably few laughs in which an insufferable teen-ager experiences a change of heart.
Review_body: Except for the few scenes between or referring to Bill Murray and his twin sons and those involving Brian Cox, this is a decidedly unfunny comedy. The hero is,  I suppose, intended to be viewed as irrepressible when in fact, he's insufferable. The filmmakers try to humanize him by giving him a dead mother and a good-hearted dad but they can't mask the fact that for the most of the film he's simply an obnoxious weasel. I found myself rooting against him at every turn and his change of heart at the end felt completely contrived. This is a mean- spirited little film that lacks the nerve to remain true to its own nastiness, opting instead for a safe "feel good" ending which is so dramatically dishonest as to be insulting

Review title: Off-beat and extremely original script, Bill Murray's performance is unbelievable.
Review_body: The script and plot are as engaging as they are twisted.  Murray is the best as I have ever seen him-it's a perfect role for him.  The seventies psychedelic soundtrack is fresh.  The character of Max is one of the most complex roles and is capable of carrying the film alone.

Review title: Definitely the funniest movie of the year
Review_body: 'Rushmore' was a rare treat of a film that was different without blatantly trying.  It was cool and original without being trendy.  It was hilariously funny without being gimmicky.  It had great, strong characters who were all so believable.  It also was a good story without a plot that punched you in the face, but rather hid behind the tree like Bill Murray in the memorable finger-painting scene.  Jason Schwartzman will be a star, and hopefully some day Bill Murray will get proper recognition for being one of the funniest men in the world. 'Rushmore' may not be for everybody, but if you don't like it the first time you see it, go see it again.  Movies like this don't come out too often, don't under-appreciate this one.

Review title: Surreal, oddly touching, and painfully amusing
Review_body: First, I need to correct two things that were said in previous comments:1.  The main character is not named Rushmore, Rushmore is the school.  The main character is Max Fisher.2.  One of the characters that was attracted to Miss Cross was already a smoker (Bill Murray's character), and the other one soon became a smoker for her, just as he saved Latin classes (which, by the way, he got cancelled) and tried to build her an aquarium.This movie was a surprise.  I'm not at all shocked that so many people have expressed their dislike for it, as you can feel nearly everything the characters are going through, and many people just aren't ready for that kind of realism.  It's not a comedy (although there are some moments that made me laugh out loud), it's not a drama, it's not anything, other than maybe a character study, and an explanation of how one young man learns to cope with everything.If you can handle it, this is a fantastic movie.

Over the last 5-6 months ive been watching films that have disappointed me and left a sort of emptiness inside me. Then along came Rushmore and yes, that emptiness soon went. In fact Rushmore filled the hole (so to speak) so well that i really cant imagine anything beating it. Its not just the perfect directorial technique or the once in a career script writers life script that does it. So many people on here have put the film down in so many different ways and of course thats fine. What these people have to ask is what did they expect from this film? Its everything anyone who wanted to be entertained/inspired could ask for. The intelligent yet charmingly vulnerable Max, the seemingly stone cold Mr blume who turns out to be completely the opposite, its perfect. I cant say anything else that will make you want to watch this but i can say this, once in a while films come along that are truly original, these films live in the memory for a long time and question the ideology of..life, its true and i might sound strange for saying it but those of you reading this and have seen the film and either enjoyed it/hated it might want to ask yourselves this question...what is the secret?Who knows?

Review title: A creative, quirky, humorous and well written film.
Review_body: Max Fisher (Jason Schwartzman) is a character you believe is a bit demented but through the course of the film you end up appreciating his style. I believe we all know some form of "Max Fisher" in high school... not an academic achiever but a mover/shaker. The type that ends up on his feet and does some remarkable things. That is the case in this film. He operates at a level far beyond his years, no wonder he desires an older woman and is close friends with a late 40-ish millionaire.I really liked this film on so many levels :Bill Murray's deadpan looksthe soundtrack... so appropriate during certain scenesthe whole supporting cast (especially Max's sidekick Kirk)scene sequencingthe character's attireOverall, a good quality film by Wes Anderson.

Review title: b e a u t i f u l: the ultimate feel-good movie
Review_body: This movie was absolutely beautiful. The script was hilarious, the characters were unique, the score was infectious and the direction was sparkling youthful ingenuity.I love this movie so much because it has to be the only movie (or one of the rare,rare movies) that made me feel this great after I saw it.  It is the ultimate feel-good movie because it has ZERO amount of cheese and just the right dollop of..umm "feel-goodness" for lack of a better term.Max Fischer is the best character I've seen on screen.  What fascinates me about him is that technically he is so unreal--I don't know anyone and I can't imagine anyone being close to a Max Fischer--and yet in the movie he is made real, he is made incarnate as a believable human being--one with passions, faults, quirks, mannerisms, etc.In my opinion the movie was really about the maturing of Max Fischer. Max Fischer was a guy boy could--and did--do anything. From his enrollment in Rushmore at age seven he was an overachieving freak, an oversuccessful success story.  And in that sense, he was spoiled. Then he falls in love with Miss Cross and for the first time ever he has a goal he cannot achieve. By the end of the movie he has grown up because he lets this goal go; this shows in the resolution between him and Cross and Herman (Murray).There were so many beautiful parts in this movie: Max's speech in his new public school (he was a fish out of water, it was hilarious); the part when Max introduces Herman to his dad, a barber and *not* a brain surgeon; Max's first meeting with Miss Cross.. Every scene in this movie is perfect; the fact that the movie doesn't drag is a major plus.All in all, I loved this movie. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys a funny, feel-good movie.by the way, can someone please give me another word for "feel-good"?!?!

I have seen this movie probably 10 times, and everytime I watch it, I love it.  For those who don't think it's funny, well, they really don't get it. It's not Adam Sandler, nor is it American Pie.  The humour relies on quirkiness, irony, and just the plain bizarre.  None of it is over the top, and that's why it's so great.  The fact that the humour isn't blatent yet still incredibly funny makes a great comedy.  Bill Murray is incredibly funny, doing the same shtick he does in The Man Who Knew Too Little (a pretty good film) and Charlie's Angels (God Awful crap).  Olivia Williams is incredibly beautiful, and Jason Schwartzman makes the film.  He's uncanny wit and his odd looks make him perfect for the role of Max.  Besides Stanley Kubrick's Dr. Strangelove (which also doesn't use the in your face bodily fluids/functions humour, yet is funny), Rushmore is my favorite movie. This is a must see for anyone who wants to laugh while still watching a great and meaningful movie.

On the artsy side, I'm not a huge Bill Murray fan, and if you're not either: don't be scared.  The movie is great, the star is the kid, the story is phenomenal, the subtle (and not so subtle) references to other movies are hilarious, the commentary on public schools it biting, the view of childhood is insightful and witty.  You liked "Saving Grace" and "The Big Lebowski" you'll like this.

I thought that this film was one of the best I have seen in quite some time. How refreshing it was to go the picture theatre and not have over-the-top special effects try to quite literally blow you off your seat. A simple story, no violence and an inspirational finale. Im not  totally against violence or special effects in films yet it was good to see real characters effectively  portray the ideals of an excellently written tale. I wont explain the film, I'll just let you discover that for yourself.

Wes Anderson shows his inner toxicity. The lead character, Max Fischer, is unbearably emotionally abusive and main goal throughout the movie is to escape the friend zone that his teacher, Rosemary Cross, has put him in. The female lead is degraded to a token whose only positive experiences in the movie are designed by men trying to get into her pants. "No" is never accepted as an answer and her good heart is taken advantage of by the minute. As a person with a bit of empathy this hurts to watch and distracts from the creativity that was poured into this movie.

I enjoyed this film a great deal, having had some experience with private schools and all the shenanigans that transpire there! Bill Murray gives us one of his 'gruff yet tender' performances that never fail to enchant, and the lovely Olivia Williams matches him emotion for emotion, but the film really belongs to young Jason Schwartzman, who all but steals every scene he's in. Hilarious and dark, this is one of the best 'indy films' I've seen!

Review title: Subtle brand of humor makes Rushmore unique
Review_body: Rushmore stands out as a comedy because it is not just a string of jokes, but more than a sum of it's parts. You could not expect to tune in half-way through and still understand the humor, or the drama. You could not turn off your brain (a prerequisite to enjoy most comedies in theaters these days) and still enjoy the film. Wes Anderson's direction is fresh and, along with the soundtrack, makes the movie very lighthearted and fun. I can't name another movie to liken it to, besides it's successor, The Royal Tenenbaums.

Review title: Speechless: One of the All-time Great Films
Review_body: There's no real reason to critique this film because it's as close to perfect as any movie can get. Plus, it has been reviewed over 500 times on this site alone.One important aspect of this film, which is overlooked in practically every online review that I've read, is Wes Anderson's nod to the world of J.D. Salinger. The parallels between Holden Caulfield and Max are numerous, and when considered in light of THE ROYAL TENENBAUMS (with its scenes at the museum and the b.b. gun battles), the canon of Wes Anderson is one that has been greatly colored by the imagination of J.D. Salinger. From Max's red hat to his expulsion, the film touches on many ideas from THE CATCHER IN THE RYE. Thematically, the works are quite similar and share an idiosyncratic mood.The other great influence on Wes Anderson, which is even more obvious to any student of film, is the work of Hal Ashby. In particular, the symmetry of Hal Ashby's shots in films like HAROLD AND MAUDE and BEING THERE. Watch RUSHMORE followed by HAROLD AND MAUDE followed by ROYAL TENENBAUMS followed by BEING THERE and you'll completely understand this sentiment.Where will THE LIFE AQUATIC fit into this equation?!?!?

Max (Schwartzman) is king or extra-curricular activities but his school work is suffering. Enter the elementary school teacher that he falls in love with, and throw the fact that Max's industrialist friend is after her too into the mix, and you get a whole lot of complications. It's a great funny romantic awkward movie. That makes you keep interest the whole time because you don't know what will happen next. It's a movie for all ages. Max fisher is an awkward adventurous confident kid who does everything he can to get the second grade teacher to like him back. I recommend this movie to a friend.
Michael Vino

Review title: I guess I just don't get it.
Review_body: While this movie certainly had its moments, over all it just didn't work for me.  The characters didn't seem self consistent, and I couldn't figure out why they were behaving the way they were most of the time.  Add in the sometimes jerky editing and lukewarm acting and you get a final product that is less than satisfying.

I sneaked into this film back when it was still in the movie theater because i am of the opinion that if i have to pay $9 to get into the place, I should be able to see at least 2 movies.  Anyway, I started snorting out little surprised laughs in the first few minutes and ended up leaving the theater with a smile planted on my face that lasted for hours afterwards.  The scene where Bill Murrary gives the teacher a letter from Max and then sprints away and the dance at the end are two of my favorite scenes from any movie. Can't wait for the next wes anderson movie.

This movie was so endearingly offbeat and dry that I had to love it.  From the team that created Bottle Rocket comes another highly original story. There is no high principle or morals to discuss over coffee here, but rather the ingenuity of putting together eccentric characters.  I'm going to call this a feel good movie because the filmakers obviously have an optimism about being a dreamer and following the path that you make for yourself.  I laughed OK.

Review title: The most boring movie I have ever seen.
Review_body: This is absolutely the most boring movie I have ever seen. You spend the entire first hour waiting for something to happen, and then when you realize it won't, the movie throws just barely enough interesting scenes to keep you from walking out.It's billed as a comedy, but the entire movie has just one funny scene, and that's the one they showed in the preview. (Guy in O.R. scrubs, main character says Oh aRe you?)The acting is good and the characters look good, but the script is missing. Quite simply nothing much happens. The main character does things for no particular reason, i.e. things don't occur in any particular sequence, nor does one action seem to lead to another. And the movie never bothers to explain why he does the stuff that he does do, it seems totally random.The "romance" or even the plays the main character put on are never fleshed out. There are numerous random scenes that have nothing to do with what came before or after, they could have been cut out and no one would have noticed - in fact 80% of the story could have been cut out without anyone noticing. You could have also taken the film, cut it into scenes and put it back together in a random order and no one would notice.In other words there is no story, only a collection of (well acted) scenes. If you like that sort of stuff go see this, but if you want an actual story I can't think of a movie with less of one.I can't even begin to describe how boring this show is, the only thing in it that doesn't suck is the pretty girl, and cute kids.

Review title: one of the most under-rated movies......
Review_body: In viewing "Rushmore" for a second time, I picked up a lot of the little things in the movie that make it so great.  The pool scene with the Bill Murray character is one of the best directed scenes in the movie. You can feel his depression.  But the movie is so much more.  Listen to the way the characters talk to each other, react to each other, listen to each other. Its the way real people act, and unfortunately it happens all too little in movies. Also note the last scene (the dance) and how the director (Anderson)has assembled every supporting character there.  It truly is a smart film.

A movie that makes you realize what dull predictable formula pap so many are nowadays.  Rushmore will keep you guessing what the fate of these likeable (!) human (!) characters will turn out to be.  It is truly hilarious without making the characters seem like marionettes playing out gags.And Bill Murray is the king of 'em all, y'all.

Review title: slapstick isn't the only way to achieve laughter
Review_body: for all you chris farley and adam sandler fans, wait for their next lemon-uva-movie, and let the intelligent people have the good seats at rushmore.   This movie does not cater to the half-minded, myopic film goer-s who just wanna sit and eat popcorn.  This movie must be thought about. Every little comment adds character and reality to the script, and Wes doesn't feel like he should have to show you when to laugh, those who pay attention and focus will fall in love with this movie.  Those who wait for scenes of bodyparts in zippers and waterboys tackling school teachers will be disappointed; i counted only one slapstick joke in the entire movie.  For those who judge it based on the color of trees during different seasons, be sure to note that the entire movie was shot in houston, and i only noticed one shot with any kind of temperate plant life, so Wes completely blew me away with his sets--i know, i'm trying to make tropical central florida look like connecticut--Jason S. is completely comfortable as a character, among acting virtuosos Bill M. and Olivia W.  It was also great to see some of the people from Bottle Rocket, who were just as good in this movie--Kumar is the best!!!--The thing that makes this movie so great is that the writers, Wes A. and Owen W. didnt seem to change their character and style to create this movie, and the entire film gives the air of "i don't care if no one likes this, this is the way we do movies"   Almost as if it was accepting the fact that some would love it, and others would hate it, unlike other films today [cough 8mm cough] and don't even tell me this thing didn't have style...anyone would be hard pressed to match this style, visually or technically. BRAVO!

Review title: This movie was not worth the price of admission.
Review_body: I found this film to be almost devoid of humor, the principal characters to be annoying and unrealistic, the cinematography lacking in color and appeal, and worst of all, Max annoyed the living hell out of me. I kept resisting the urge to reach into the screen and slap him to his senses.
This movie was horrible.  From the start, it wanders aimlessly and never attracts a viewing audience.  Do yourself a favor and pass it by.

It's been over 24 hours since I've seen Rushmore and I'm still smiling.  I laughed until I cried, but mostly I could not wipe the smile off my face. It was the most enjoyable film experience I can remember having.The performances of Bill Murray and especially Jason Schwartzman (he is not getting his due!) were perfect and I don't even believe in perfection.  I ask anybody who criticized their performances how they would do it?  These guys did not miss a single beat.This is writing.  This is acting.   This is a great movie.

If you've ever felt unrequited love, this movie is for you.  A wonderfully comic, yet touching, love tale that satisfies both the intellect as well as the heart.  Bill Murray is his best as the disappointed paramour who's life, despite great financial riches, is bitter and empty.  Jason Swartzman played the role of Max Fisher perfectly, capturing both the adolescent love and Holden Caulfied-like angst of his character.This film should be in everyone's collection and certainly on the Top 250 list.

Review title: A pure stroke of genius. The best comedy of the decade.
Review_body: Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson have written a hilarious and touching comedy that harkens back to great 1980's. I have seen this movie twice and loved it. I have been a fan of their work since the now classic BOTTLEROCKET. Their teaming with Bill Murray, the king of comedy, is a pure stroke of genius. The writing is excellent, camera work fresh, and the performances by Jason Schwartzman, Murray, and Olivia Williams are superb. The script was probably my favorite aspect of the film, utilizing lines from other films, old racial slurs rarely heard today, and never has the phrase 'hand-job' been so funny. Watch closely for surprise appearances by BOTTLEROCKET alum's Luke Wilson(Owen's brother), Kumar as Mr. Little Jeans, and Futureman(also a Wilson brother) as the baseball coach. Also, Max's final play, a sendup of APOCALYPSE NOW, is hilarious. 10 out of 10.

Review title: A brilliant film worth another look...
Review_body: I just saw Rushmore, and all I can say is "WOW!" I'm not a Gen-Xer, yuppie, or a teenager, so the negative reviews that cite this film as comprehensible only to these groups are invalid for me. This was an odd, unique little film whose comedy comes from characterization, not one-liners or vulgarity (I'm no snob, though; I LOVED Kingpins). This film walked the razor's edge between quirkiness for its own sake and true insight into the human soul and, in my opinion, succeeded. Interestingly, the trailers for this film turned me off; it just looked like another teen comedy; a bit different, perhaps, than the current vogue of films using TV icons who have the vapid look of JC Penney catalog models, but looking a little too self-consciously hip and arty nevertheless. How wrong I was! I suggest that anyone who disliked this film but finds it crossing their mind from time to time should watch it again. You might change your opinion.

Review title: As unique a film as America has ever produced.
Review_body: Wes Anderson is not a simple person, yet he directs films about simple people whose quirky personalities create somewhat complicated stories. Sort of...Well as you can tell, describing a Wes Anderson picture is a perplexing task.Rushmore is a story about a 15 year old scatter-brained jack-of-all-trades named Max (played by newcomer Jason Schwartzman).  Max is given scholarship to a prestigious prep school following the success of a stageplay he writes while in the 2nd grade.  Life thereafter is not easy for Max for his IQ is not quite average, yet he dreams big.  One day Max befriends a wealthy booster named Herman.  Bill Murray's portrayal of this character was Oscar-worthy.  He wishes he had a son like Max and makes his malcontent with his own children obvious throughout the picture.  Ultimately, Max and Herman fall in love with one of Max's teachers, Mrs. Cross, and what ensues is one of the most charming and unique love triangles ever filmed.With Rushmore, subtlety is everywhere: cinematography, scene composition, dialogue, and of course acting.  What makes this film so wonderful is the manner in which the audience can find faults with all the characters yet they're so richly developed that you still embrace them.  There is no over-the-top conflict between characters in Rushmore.  In one pivotal scene Max and Mrs. Cross exchange sentiments that they've never met a person quite like the other.  I've never quite seen a film like Rushmore.If there is one minor critique of Rushmore, it would be that Anderson seems to be intentionally unconventional with scene transition, which was more annoying than artistic.All considered, I still consider this gem a splendid 10/10.*psssst* Make sure you see "Bottle Rocket" too!

Review title: A wonderful movie the second, third, fourth and fifth time around.
Review_body: When I first saw this movie, I didn't really have any good or bad thoughts of it, I had expected the humor to be the style of many Bill Murray movies I had seen.  It wasn't until I had watched it one day on TV, knowing what to expect, that I really enjoyed the movie.  If you saw it once and didn't like it, see it again, if you saw it once and liked it, see it again anyway, repeat viewings of this movie make it better, but for those who haven't yet seen it, don't expect too much obvious humor, a lot is implied, and done very well, at that.Overall, I give Rushmore a 9.6 out of 10.Side note: the only movie I have given 10 out of 10 to is "Dr. Strangelove  or: how I learned to stop worrying and love the bomb".

Rushmore is one of my very favorite movies of all time.  I think it deserves an oscar nomination for Schwartzman and Murray, plus best picture for the upcoming academy awards.  Alas, it will never win because its too smart and too complicated for the old fogies in the voting circle.It is a great movie with black humor, romance, and redemption.  Although its a little sappy, Owen Wilson and Wes Anderson should get more recognition for this work but won't because this movie grossed less than $20M.  Also, buy the soundtrack, even if you didn't like the movie.

I have to say right now that this is one of the most enjoyable films I've ever had the pleasure the view.  I hate that there is a thousand word limit on these things, because I could talk about this one all day.  Never before have I seen a film that so perfectly melted the humor of a situation with the pain and awkwardness that ultimately result in each scene.  It is truly fascinating to see how these characters react to each situation presented. Sometimes we got humor, other times we got these incredibly complex and painful situations.  What makes things interesting is that we never knew what was going to come about, and that was the true test for Wes Anderson here.  It is a daunting task for a director to try and evoke so much humor, pain, sorrow, and ultimate redemption in one film, just ask Robert Altman, and Anderson does it masterfully here.  It is nice to see Anderson growing up and coming in to his own as a director. I enjoyed his previous Bottle Rocket, a very interesting film, but found it a little boring in stretches. With Rushmore, Anderson has created a masterpiece of a film that is an instant American classic.  Bravo!
it took too long to get there. If you are over 40, forget about this one. The ending is cute, but the rest of the movie was boring. I kept waiting for something to happen, but it never did.

At the center, an odd boy named Max. Max is at a difficult age where boys become men. Max is unique. His enjoyment of life comes from putting on plays and participating in other extra-curricular activities. No doubt, he presents himself as an intelligent person, but his grades are lacking. What do grades measure anyway. He has determination and heart. His pursuits in the game of love show his awkwardness and inexperience. He competes with millionaire Herman Blume for the affections of a 1st grade teacher. This is a great film about the two constants, the unobtainable and the one right in front of your nose. Bill Murray gives a performance similar to Groundhog Day, but much more subtle. Jason Schwartzman amazing as Max Fischer. And Olivia Williams makes a very convincing object of affection. Much better than her role in the Postman

Review title: One of the best comedies I've seen.
Review_body: Extremely funny. Max is a unique 'student' who wants to stay at Rushmore for the rest of his life, and uses his extra curricular status to try and score first grade teacher Miss Cross. I enjoyed the acting talent very much, particularly the young Mason Gamble's Dirk Calloway, and Jason Schwartzman's (nice but slightly insane) Max Fischer. Bill Murray's facial expressions as Herman Blume are downright hilarious. One of the best comedies I've seen.

No, Bill Murray isn't all that funny in this film. What do you expect? He's a flexible actor playing a deeply depressed character.  Did Robin Williams's performance in "Good Will Hunting" leave you rolling in the floor with laughter?Sure, Max is a jerk through much of the film, but he progressively matures from his experiences.  It's called character development.Yes, it is slow.  Thank God!  We can immerse ourselves, notice all the minute pleasures that make up every scene, the little nuances of pacing, scenery, and behavior - The split-second, uneasy expression that Miss Rosemary gives Max after she shakes his hand - Murray carelessly tossing golfballs into the pool  Ever noticed how the sky overhead matches the mood of the central character in the shot (sunny or gray)?  oh, I can go on and on. Really, it does merit several viewings.It's interesting reading the reviews of those who liked it.  They each mention something different - a different line, scene, twist on a theme. For those of you who hated it - go back to your asinine television sitcoms. Leave the films to those who appreciate creativity and beauty.

Review title: One of the most beautiful movies I've ever seen.
Review_body: This 1998 film written by Wes Anderson and actor/writer Owen Wilson is without a doubt one of the most beautiful movies I've ever seen.  The gorgeous visuals set a perfect backdrop for some of the greatest movie dialogue of all time.  Between the amazingly witty comments made by both Max Fischer (Jason Schwartzman) and Herman Blume (Bill Murray, in a truly Oscar worthy performance, he was unjustly robbed of a nomination), the producers implement some great, offbeat music that fits perfectly into the film.  This music accurately projects what Max is feeling, and it progresses as he does throughout the film, as we see just how far a young man will go in the name of love.

Max Fisher is one of the most original characters I have seen in recent film.  In the tradition of Dignan in "Bottle Rocket," Max is an ambitious person, whose reach is far greater than his grasp. Both of these movies are among my favorites and I look forward to many more from Wes Anderson and his co-writer Owen Wilson.

This movie is a joy. A bittersweet comedy about the life and loves of a 15 year old school boy (Max). This character could have so easily been unlikable that it's almost with disbelief that I found myself sympathizing with him as his life began to tumble out of control. Bill Murray is perfect as Max's friend and father of two of his classmates. He is completely restrained and proves that he can act without having to play the fool. This film is funny because of the sharp observations it makes, if you want your comedy laugh out loud ridiculous then try something else. The music is great, fitting the mood perfectly and the plot moves along at a quick enough pace to keep you completely absorbed until the end. Superb, 9/10.

Review title: Wes Anderson's breakthrough film is fantastic!
Review_body: "I like your nurse scrubs, guy", says the drunk, pretentious sophomore at the table. The man he was addressing responds that they are O.R. Scrubs. Ever the comedian, the sophomore asks, "O.R. they?" The lonely, rich industrialist stifles a laugh, and the 1st grade teacher, dating the O.R nurse, scolds the sophomore, who is in love with her. This scene sets up the characters in Rushmore very well. It is a delightful story with quirky characters, hilarious jokes, and stunning visuals, all signatures of Wes Anderson. Owen Wilson and Anderson co-write, who are a fantastic team, and it has great performances. Just an all around great film.

Review title: Mr. Larson is right on the money.....
Review_body: Beautiful film, realistic, great dialogue, casting, character development, and soundtrack.  Anything I say would be understating this wonderful piece. It IS for all of us who see the world in maybe a little to romantic light and those of us who can't seem to bring ourselves to do the trivial tasks of life without drifting off into our own selfish little worlds.  Beautiful film.

I saw this on DVD recently without knowing much about it at all. I must say that I was very surprised. I was not at all ready for what I got. The movie is incredibly charming and funny. The nonchalant, odd humor is very entertaining and kept me laughing off my seat. Bill Murray is great and Jason Schwartzman also does a good job. The plot had some minor weak spots, but a very good character to it. I saw the Royal Tenebaums back in the theaters so I do not really remember it very much to compare, but I do not remember enjoying it as much as I did this. I don't know anything about the hype or over-rating (as some other user said) but this is a quality movie. I recommend it.

The concept behind Rushmore is novel and the characters are well cast. The protagonist is a socially-awkward, lovable, pathological liar who falls in love with a private school teacher who's a bit too old for him.Rushmore is subtly hilarious. Much of the film's humor derives from Fischer's character flaws and the awkwardness of the situations in which he puts himself. Viewers accustomed to overt humor probably won't crack a smile, but more attentive viewers will crack a few good laughs.The soundtrack suits the naive nature of the protagonist and the film itself. By no means is it amazing, but it definitely works.The plot seems to meander a lot. The movie often feels more like a collection of marginally connected moments in Max Fischer's life than a coherent story.For most movies, a loose plot is a huge shortfall. But Rushmore is just too darn heartwarming and novel for this to matter much. In fact, I would argue that Rushmore actually benefits from it. Despite how the film meanders, Rushmore is still easy to follow, and the lack of direction seems to contribute to its charming naivety. I was never confused over what was happening; I was only ever puzzled as to where the film was going.Rushmore is a quirky, naive, and rather unimportant film. With this in mind, it's easy to see why people who take themselves too seriously would hate Wes Anderson's woefully neglected gem.

Some people may consider that The Royal Tenenbaums was Wes Anderson's best, but Rushmore was what really started Anderson to write dark, ironic comedies.  Also, unlike some writers, Anderson made his perfect movie on only his second time out.  The sheer brilliance and funniness of Rushmore is forgotten by many because of its quirkiness and dark attitude.  I would recomend it for anyone who enjoyed the Royal Tenenbaums or who is looking for movie that not just makes you laugh, but also makes you think.

Rushmore was a delightful surprise to me, I'd never heard about it. It's a great comedy starring Jason Schwartzman and Bill Murray. Max Fisher (Schwartzman) is a student who falls in love with Miss Rosemary Cross, a teacher at the university. This love is not only impossible because of the age difference, but also because Rosemary is widowed from her late husband of which she hasn't fully recovered from. But Max is a clever boy and tries to win her love with the help of the university's principle Herman Blume (Bill Murray). They're good friends and both have the same kind of humor. But when Herman meets Rosemary he falls in love with her too. Now the friends become rivals. This creates some very funny moments between the two of them. This movie is brilliant for it entire credits. The writing and directing is outstanding and the performances of the actors are nothing less. Schwartzman is so dedicated to his acting that you don't see him as an actor but as Max Fisher, the intelligent and devoted  student. Bill Murray again proves he's the king of comedy. His 'dry' humor, as we call it in Holland, is perfectly in line with the sarcastic humor of Schwartzman. It's the same sort of comedy as 'Wonder Boys'. It truly is one of the best comedies I've ever seen. A must see

This is one of the best movies I have ever seen.  You have to see it to really understand what I am talking about.  It is very subtle, so don't expect big Hollywood hoopla, but if you take the time to soak it in, hopefully you'll appreciate its art as much as I do.

I have visited this site for a number of years, but this is the first time I have felt compelled to sign up and comment.  I loved this movie when it first came out; I bought the DVD and have watched it maybe twenty times.  Wes Anderson is the greatest filmmaker of my generation in my opinion. He inspires me to be a comedic director.I have to admit Bill Murray and Jason Schwartzman make this movie, but it's Wes's attention to detail, his pacing and his timing that really makes this a great film.  The music, the editing and the production design are all very unique to Wes's style.I can't wait to see the next film, Life Aquatic to see how Wes does without Owen Wilson as a co-writer.  Rushmore will always be an inspiration to me personally and Wes Anderson's masterpiece.

Review title: Very well written, acted and directed.
Review_body: Well I saw this movie some time ago. It's in the style of Wes Anderson's later movies , "The Royal Tenenbaums" and "Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou". The movie is a bit surrealistic and sour but the humor is deep and when you think back about this movie you can remember lots of it's jokes like how the main character, Marx Fischer used Latin in his latest play. Bill Murray was just as great as in his other Anderson movies. If you're looking for a comedy where you laugh at every scene this is not the movie but as a surrealistic comedy the movie is great. Also I liked some of the music in the film for example Rolling Stones and Cat Stevens. I think that Wes Anderson is a really special director and his style is of that kind that not nearly all of people like his movies.Mr. Hawkins
Problem is Jason, I cant stand him.... He was dull, bad acting and annoying. The story was boring too and nothing much happen...

A young teen who is more interested in the extra-cirruclar activities than the actual cirruclar learning required. Wes Anderson the director comes together with Owen Wilson to show us a film about friendship, love, and what is it like to be a youth at Rushmore academy. A film with a very different feel that will leave you loving the flaws that each of us has and how we can use the things we love to accomplish many great things. I would recommend this movie to others and I encourage you to watch the other films by Wes Anderson.

"Who cares?" would sum up our comments.  We four adults sat there looking at each other, wondering where this thing got an 8.2 star rating.  We cared nothing about any of the players, tho't the hero rather disgusting, couldn't believe another movie with a 25 year old woman hooking up with a 60 year old.  We only paid $1.00 to see it, so maybe it was worth a dollar, but this thing made Wag The Dog look like Gone with the Wind.  Avoid this.

Review title: I loved it, my girlfriend hated it!
Review_body: Just the kind of offbeat, quirky comedy that I was hoping it was.  Besides skillfully shot and edited, the acting is of a generally high standard, especially Schwartzman.  The feeling of awkwardness is sufficient, but never cringe-making, and adds to the almost surreal, fairytale quality the film has. Not everybody's cup of tea, I can at least see that, but if you want to see Bill Murray's paunch, there's no better film this year.

You know, I find it difficult to dislike this movie.  And this coming from someone who is adamant about not believing the hype.Rushmore is startlingly amazing, especially since the trend in recent comedies has been to appeal to an audience of 14-year-old boys by concentrating on bodily-function jokes, scantily clad, 20-year-old women, and a substantial lack of plot.  I haven't seen a movie this witty and hilariously subtle since "Dr. Strangelove;"  the acting is terrific, the directing is impeccable, and the script trusts the intelligence of its audience; never once do you suffer through a drawn-out monologue or boring voice-over explaining what you already know to be happening.I've read comments from people who didn't "get" the movie, who couldn't understand what was even going on in the film.  This is a forgivable offense, because you can't really expect an audience that has been served with fast-paced, plotless action movies and brainless, puerile, obscenity-driven comedies to recognize a good story when they see one. Rushmore is always entertaining, and provides something most recent movies have not: originality.

A fresh and invigorating movie, unlike anything out there.  Jason Schwartzman is genius, but all acting, photography, editing, and music work together to form a complete world, and it's sure a fun, goofy and unpredictable one.  Probably even funnier than BOTTLE ROCKET, and that's saying a lot.

Review title: Pure Genius, the only words to describe Rushmore.
Review_body: Pure Genius, the only words to describe Rushmore. Rushmore is one of the best films of 1998 and is one of the best films I've ever seen, and one of the funniest. Rushmore re-teams the team who brought us the cult hit "Bottle Rocket" Rushmore focuses on Max Fischer, a student at the elite Rushmore private school. Max is the founder, president of literally all the after school clubs and extra curricular activites. He's president of the Backgammon club, edits the school yearbook and newspaper, and even has his own team of actors "The Max Fischer Players". But what this highly involved student doesn't have is good grades. He soon befriends a local millionnaire, who is played by Bill Murrary, in which he does a brilliant job portraying Mr. Blume. He deserves an Oscar nod. He also befriends and begins a crush on to the first grade teacher at Rushmore, Miss Cross. And so begins of the most funniest and entertaining movie love triangles. Rushmore is very well done, it's funny, it has a deep good script, you don't know which way it's going to turn. This is a great follow up to "Bottle Rocket". I simply love this movie and was very fortuante to see in its one week release. Don't worry the rest of you, Rushmore opens nationwide in February. I can't wait to see it again. A masterpiece.

Review title: THE most refreshing movie in years.
Review_body: It feels inexpensive, it looks inexpensive but the storyline and characters are so rich, you know you've hit gold.  This is by far one of the best films I've seen in years.  The Story Centers on Max Fischer (Jason Schwartzman), a 15 year old boarding school student who has cruised by on raw charm and the ability to 'play' on his raw talents.  His talents don't include your typical academic subjects, but rather the much more important life skills of making others believe in your ability to perform the impossible. This quickly turns to a quirky love story that pits the much older millionaire Herman Blume (Bill Murray) against Max for the affections of elementary school marm Rosemary Cross (Olivia Williams). It would be impossible to accurately explain all the clever twists, turns and lessons that both Max and Herman learn in their quest.  Just go see it!  There has been talk in all the film trades of an Oscar nomination for Murray.  In this reviewers opinion, they will do a grave injustice if they overlook Jason Schwartzman. His presence is mature, subtle and endearing. It is absolutely worth the price of a second and third admission!

This film is one of the most moving films i have ever seen. I was almost crying for the whole film, and this is a hard ask for a 17 year old male. It's funny, sad, weird, off-beat and totally and uterly irreverent. In one word brilliant, encompassing humor, romance with social issues and the stark reality of life, it really opened up my eyes to myself and to the world at large. I feel that sometimes i am Max Fischer and so are most people i know. Must see film.

If you ever want to know if Bill Murray can sleepwalk, watch this flick; this has to be the biggest waste of talent...  I had great expectations for this flick, and what I really want is a refund of the time I wasted on this turkey.  I've encountered better humor on soup labels and income tax forms. Too bad the lowest IMDB rating is one, this flick deserves a zero.

this was one of the best movies i've seen in a couple years. i am a big fan of bottlerocket, so i thought i would probably enjoy this movie as well. but it was even better than i thought it would be. rushmore has heart and comedy combined by dark settings and deep characters. and how did bill murray not get nominated for an oscar? the academy is insane.

Review title: Brilliant, beautiful film re-affrms Anderson's skill
Review_body: When I first saw Bottle Rocket a little over a year ago, I knew I had seen something special. Rushmore, the second film from writing team Owen Wilson and director Wes Anderson, proves that not only was the charm of Bottle Rocket not a fluke, but also that even the best can get even better. Watching Rushmore was an almost transcendent experience. This near perfect film works on every conceivable level, from the brilliant script to the incredible performances by all of the actors, all of which is directed with a flawless grace and style. Rushmore very well may be my new favorite movie. I can't wait to see what Wilson and Anderson come up with next.

Review title: Rushmore is a fantastic film. Extremely funny, witty and touching. 9/10 stars!
Review_body: Rushmore is a superb film.  Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson have come up with a winner that is even better than their first film, Bottle Rocket.  This film is one of the best to come out recently.  It is incredibly funny, witty and touching.  9/10 stars!

Review title: Rushmore is the best movie I've seen in years
Review_body: When you boil it down, people watch films for entertainment--this is quite possible what makes it such an art.  This is what makes Rushmore wonderful. Every element of Rushmore made it a potential classic.  The wonderful directing could be seen through the many wonderful actors.  The editing was wonderful, dialogue intelligent and witty, and the cinematography turned an otherwise mundane setting and made it beautiful.  The techniques used are fresh and productive.  Anderson is a breath of fresh air to modern cinematic direction.  All intellectually redeeming characteristics aside, this movie was hilarious.  It is wonderful story that is expressed beautifully on film and I highly recommend it.

I could not generate any sympathy for the plight of the main characters. Would I want to know them in 5 or 10 years? No.  So why should I care about there little troubles today?  Being "quirky" is not in itself bad or unsympathetic, but there was no depth given to the main characters to be interested in whether they got on with their lives.

Review title: how many movies about high school rejects can Hollywood make?
Review_body: There's a lot of movies out there about high school misfits..."welcome To The Dollhouse" and "Pecker" and two films which were done much better, but this movie has it's charming moments. Bill Murray, does he have any funny lines through the entire movie? His character is one of the least developed, and unfunny roles in the film. His role could have been done by anybody. The title character, Max Fletcher, steals the show with his popular nerdiness.  It reminded me of the John Hughes films of the '80's...it was only missing Lea Thompson. Worth renting, but i'm sorry if you wasted your money to see it in the theatre.

This had to be one of the biggest disappointments of the year.  Bill Murray plays an unbelievably pathetic tutor to the even less believable pupil, Max Fliescher.  The roles somehow reverse, but that process is as ridiculous as the meaningless plays the Tom Cruise look-a-like, but wanna be Woody Allen creates.  The loud painful laughs that come from this story is due to the absurdity of the situations.  Would a steel tycoon sacrifice $8 million to build a love note to a less than compelling love interest?  What attraction was there in a widowed kindergarten teacher who showed so much disinterest? Only blind men would think there was any possibility of romance.

If you are looking for a unique, offbeat film with solid performances, wacky humor and random stuff thrown in just for kicks, then you have come to the right place.  Rushmore has a fun energy, which keeps things interesting, and enough off-the-wall scenes to make you marvel at the pure genius and creativity of it.  Jason Schwartzman's portrayal of Max is perfect as the likeable underachieving kid with extracurriculars coming out of his ears, and a desire to impress a kindergarden teacher by building her an aquarium that she doesn't want.  Bill Murray's acting is subtle which caught me by surprise, as I was expecting his usual flamboyance. He certainly delivers a solid performance here, but perhaps not as good as all the critical acclaim and hype would suggest.  The movie does appear quite disjointed at times (but this is probably the whole point) and it certainly loses some of it's comedic steam toward the end.  All in all, if you can handle the random, quirky humor, and appreciate the subtlety, you just may end up loving this highly original film.

Review title: THIS is the comedy of the year??!?!
Review_body: This film is the benefactor of all the so-called 'dumb' comedies that have been coming out lately and so it gets called 'full of heart', 'quirky', and gets respect for having non-typical heroes.  Unfortunately, all this does not a good film make.  It's neither funny nor gripping.  Yeah, I smirked a couple of times, but it thought it was a lot funnier than it actually was and this irritated me.  Bill Murray looked like he didn't know what he was doing in the movie at all, and you didn't really care about any of the characters.  The main character was a dork without a cause and the teacher was a sweet English girl also without a cause.  I was disappointed.

Review title: Great first half, then a quick descent into creepiness
Review_body: All of the quirky atmosphere built up in the first half-hour is ruined when Max is revealed to be an obsessive creep/stalker, and it is hard to feel anything towards him for the rest of the movie. The second half of the movie fell flat after a meandering, meaningless middle that had me checking how much time was left. For a 90-minute movie to drag on into what seemed like 3 hours is not a good sign, and Rushmore ranks as one of the bigger disappointments of the year.

Forget "Shakespeare in Love" and "Saving Private Ryan"!  "Rushmore" was definitely the best movie of 1998!  Jason Schwarzman, being the nephew of Francis Ford Coppola, shines!  Thank you Talia Shire for having such wonderful offspring!  Olivia Williams, let's hope more good movies come your way (does "The Postman" ring a bell for being bad?)  Try your pick at indies.  As for Bill Murray, bravo!  I loved it!  Your best performance since "What About Bob?"  But one complaint, why didn't the Academy even nominate these three?

Most of us are boring, inclined to be spectators.  Some of us are embarrassing. Others, interesting. I'm mostly boring, as are my parents, brothers, sisters,  and friends. So there is usually a shortage of interesting people around here. So anyway, I recommend RUSHMORE because there are a few interesting characters who do some interesting things. (And to boot, there's the beautiful, if not otherwise interesting, Olivia W..) Yes, Jason S. and Bill M. do good work and their parts are well written. Seemingly forgotten, however, is Seymour Cassel, who plays Max's father: "Mr. Fischer was my father's name, call me Bert." Though his is not a plot-pivotal role, the guy's a standout as the laid-back, "hands-off" neurosurgeon/barber. I like his style, interesting. And in the end, remember, he gets the babe!(What's  next for Wes Anderson? I'll be there, even if I can't get a date.)

Rushmore is possibly the best comedy of the 1990s, but it goes further. Director Wes Anderson inculcates this rich film with incredible depth, complicated relationships, and well-acted drama to complement its great comedic overtones. Jason Schwartzman is very good as Max, making him flawed but at the same time adorable, scandelous while seeming innocent. Herman Bloom must have been created for Bill Murray, because he plays him with incredible ability and understanding of the man's unique perspective. I cannot wait for Rushmore to be released to the public on video so I may buy it and add to my four viewings.

How could anyone not like this movie?  Well cast and directed with great cinematograpic effects and a well-selected soundtrack, Rushmore is probably one of the better comedies of the decade.  Schwartzman is fantastic and well backed by the remaining cast.  Wonderful story, lovable characters well acted.  What else is there?  It's one of those movies I want to see for the first time again.  Oh well.

This movie was my personal favorite of 1998.  It was original and had great acting.  Bill Murray was hilarious even though he was very low key for his personality.  Jason Shwartzman showed he can act better than his mother, and equal to his Cousin.A 10 all the way.

I'm tired of "Art" movies. Though not a bad movie, it's one of those flicks that once you've seen it, there's no reason to go back and watch it over again. Doesn't that really define a very good movie from the others? The fact that you liked it so much that you'll probably see it again and again...etc, This certainly isnt one of those Bill Murray flicks such as GroundHog Day, that you would want to enjoy over again. No redeeming charactors...though not in and of itself a flaw; but c'mon, a late 40's man in a relationship with a 15 year old student...both competing for a teacher? Max is supposed to be a "gifted" playwrite...but we never see him on camera writing ANYTHING! Then BOOM!!! He's in a play! I love Bill Murray, and I certainly am not stereotyping him, but this is not one of his better flicks. Viewed on DVD Criterion...2 of 4 stars

My faaaaaaaavourite thing about Rushmore is...... Jason Schwartzman.., no - Olivia Williams..,no - Seymour Cassel..,no - Mason Gamble..,no - Sara Tanaka...,Bill Murray (definitely not!).Betcha can't work out when it's about to end.OH YEAH - IT'S THE SOUNDTRACK.Watched it. Loved it. fp

This movie is wonderfully subtle, one of the funniest movies I've ever seen. It has so many little things that you don't pick up on at first, you have to watch it a few times to really get the full effect of it. I like it more every time I see it, it just keeps getting funnier and funnier, like a great simpsons episode. Maybe Bill Murray's best role ever.

Review title: This is not the movie for you!
Review_body: Have you ever seen a movie that made you gag? Well I have and it's called Rushmore.  If your looking for a clever comedy and a good performance by Bill Murray, look no further than Caddyshack, but please don't waste your time and money on this movie.  The only scene in the whole movie that made me even think of laughing was when Bill Murray tripped over a fence.  The rest of this horrible bomb made me more bored than Alec Baldwin at the Jerry Louis Marathon.  Rushmore is not funny, nor is it clever, entertaining? Please!  This film has made me question the brain capacity of the actor Bill Murray.  This film left a permanent stain on my brain, which I can't stop associating with him.  Please considered these fine films instead; High Fidelity, Election,  Small Time Crooks, Caddyshack, Airplane!, or anything made by Woody Allen. Thank You for your time.

Review title: I am in love with Rushmore
Review_body: Bottom line: subtle, unique, *brilliant*."Subtle" means that a lot of people won't get it.  They'll critique its off-beat comedic timing.  They'll whine about its pace or how it doesn't really come to a climax, or praise Bill Murray's other comedic efforts in films like Caddyshack.  This is not their movie.

Review title: Rushmore is the best Wes Anderson film.
Review_body:
...and I will fight you if you disagree. 
Full of heart as well as quirk, and before that quirkiness became self conscious. Funny surprising and gorgeous.

Review title: Awesome and unique high school story!
Review_body: Most movies that revolve around a high school involve that student trying to win over a teacher for whatever reason. What makes Rushmore extremely interesting is that it also involves a successful adult with the same goal as the teenager. Overall, this was an amazing movie that was also filled with many comedic parts.

I absolutely adore this movie! I like how it shows a bit of the classic wes anderson style without going overboard in my opinion it's the perfect balance. Jason Swartzman was really good as max fischer he bodied him perfectly. It's very impressive too because prior to rushmore he had no acting experience. I love the theme and the little things that kept coming up like with the curtains and how it kind of symbolized a new beginning or the end of something. Overall I think this movie is just so good and everyone needs to watch it.

Rushmore definitely goes onto my list of top movies.  It is truly a movie that the everyday person can relate to.  The plot itself isn't too outstanding, but you can see why it is such a brilliant film once you see it.The written aspect of "Rushmore" is so well done that it's impossible to watch it and think that what's going on in the film could never really happen in daily life.  This also brings attention to the character portrayals.  Everyone in the film does an excellent job with the mixture of comedy and drama seen throughout the film.Wes Anderson is, in my opinion, a really great director.  He doesn't make films that are mainstream and will be old and forgotten about years from now.  They may be little known films, but for those that have seen a film directed by Anderson, including "Rushmore", will not soon forget it.

Caution: There are some very, very minor SPOILERS, though I think anyone who has seen the trailer wouldn't be surprised.The beauty of Rushmore is how everything comes full-circle. However zany the schemes and witty the one-liners, Rushmore stands out in my mind (and as one of my favorite movies) with its true-to-life qualities concerning love and friendship. Over the course of the film, private school sophomore Max Fisher (Jason Schwartzman) and steel-baron millionaire Herman Bloom (Bill Murray) become friends, then enemies, then friends again, however uncertain their futures are, and the same for Max and his relationship with grade-school teacher Miss Cross (Olivia Williams) and his chapel partner Dirk.
That is little to say about director Wes Anderson's now-trademark scripts (co-written with Owen Wilson) and style. Rushmore was one of the best, most original films of 1998, and prepared the public for his equally-excellent The Royal Tenenbaums. Over the course of his small filmography (also including 1996's Bottle Rocket), he has set the standard for his unparalleled mastery of the montage, most notably used in Rushmore to transition between the months of Max's sophomore year.As for the idea that Max Fisher is one of the most unlikeable characters ever conceived, I must note that I was fifteen when I first saw Rushmore, and I was reminded of myself in Max - sans the whole self-destruction and teacher-loving. So perhaps I can't understand the argument.I will openly admit that I didn't immediately praise Rushmore after my first viewing, and I urge nay-sayers to give it a second try. It is easily one of the finer American films made in the last five years, and it at least deserves some credit for its originality - something Hollywood always seems to be lacking.My score: Five stars - One of the very few five-star ratings I have given out.

I cannot believe i see this movie in 2011, but i have to appreciate every second of work that everybody did in this movie, because it's fantastic, and it sure is one of the best movies i have ever seen. The short story you heard it from the others, who didn't see this movie, must do! Because of the minimum of 10 lines, i shall tell you that you are about to see a clever boy that lives his true normality through the official life of an adolescent who has to live the school life, which is of course too formal, and his brilliant way of doing anything that is interesting will make a lot of troubles, and nevertheless being in love which will help him become what he needs to be in his life. We all went through this, but this story it's about to leave you without a breath. Go see this movie now!

Max Fisher loves Rushmore. It is his life. He spends 99% of his time starting up clubs and putting on plays. He doesnt, however, spend enough time on his school work. He meets Herman Blume after attending a speech Blume gives at Rushmore. Blume is immediately taken by Max's ambition and the two become friends.Shortly after, Max falls in love with a teacher at Rushmore, Ms Cross. He gets kicked out of Rushmore because of his bad grades and subsequently turns his attention to her. She becomes his Rushmore. Unfortunately, Blume falls in love with her too.This movie is, for lack of a better word, a masterpiece. Everything about the movie, from the acting, to the writing, to the direction are fantastic. Wes Anderson is a direction genius. His movies are very original, and still have a wide appeal. Anderson co-wrote this picture with Owen Wilson. The two also teamed up for Andersons' Bottle Rocket and The Royal Tenenbaums, in which Wilson co-starred.Jason Schwartzman, in his first role, is endearing as Max Fisher, an overachieving underachiever. Bill Murray takes a chance with Herman Bloom, a type of character he is not accustom to. Personally, I think he should have at least been awarded an Oscar nomination for this role, but the Academy turned a blind eye, much like they did with Gene Hackman in The Royal Tenenbaums. In any case, it may be the best role of his career. Rounding out the excellent cast are Olivia Williams(Ms. Cross) and Seymour Cassel(Max's dad, Bert).

In case a reader doesn't get the joke in my title it is derived from a line by Mr. Little Jeans.  Anyway, there isn't much that one can say about this extraordinary cinematic feat.  The film's theme can be summarized by the quote that Max finds inside of Edward Applebee's book in the library.  I will not state this quote but once one has seen the movie they will understand the simple premise of such a remarkable screenplay.  At the end of the day, I would have to believe that if everyone followed this mantra, of doing what they like to do, they will be happy in all that they do. That's all.

Review title: An Amazing Work of Honest Comedy
Review_body: Rushmore is a film that is so honest and direct, it's characters so certain in their words and uncompromising in their ways that you can either laugh, or you can sit back and be annoyed by this display of sheer originality. Bill Murray gives the performance of his career in a role that uncovers the darkness of his screen persona. You imagine many of his comic characters act the way Herman Blume does when they are off-screen.

Review title: Maybe it deserves another watch, maybe not
Review_body: I feel a lot of people saw this that Thought it said something profound about their youth, but I saw this at the end of high school and came off rather hating the main character. Much like Catcher in the Rye, I am unable to take seriously the angst of a person so self obsessed and was made desperately uncomfortable by the "love story". The suspension of disbelief required to stomach... that scene between the two could hold up the Bay Bridge.

Review title: On of the most beautiful movies in a long time.
Review_body: Let's see here: A movie starring Bill Murray and made by Wes Anderson and the Wilson brothers. It seems like another comedy that will be funny but not strike audiences. "Rushmore" does more than that by a long shot. This movies combines clever comedy with a beatiful love story with A GREAT story. Jason Schwartzman, who amazingly introduced his acting career in this movie, was phenomonal. He was smart, funny, and, at sometimes, loving. Bill Murray, who was nominated for many awards for his performance, just makes the screen light up when he is on it. Olivia Williams plays her charcter brilliantly, making the audience fall in love her, along with the characters. Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson write a superb screenplay for this different, great, smart story. I forgot to mention the great sountrack, which happens to make mos of the movie.  This movie makes you feel so good after you see it. It makes you appreciate love, friendship, and family most of all. PLEASE SEE THIS MOVIE AND SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT IT.

This movie had all the elements of a great film.  It was original, was wacky yet serious, had excellent characters, and it had great music.  This is a story about Max but in a lot of ways it's about what drives us.  Max is a very driven kid and that changes in the movie.  His characters evolution is done brilliantly and is shown through his interactions with Bill Murray and Olivia Williams.  Yet it isn't just about Max, all the characters are interesting even that crabby Scottish guy.  Blended with good music and an engaging story of love, loss, and obsession Rushmore is definitely one of Wes Anderson's best.

Right before turning in, the girlfriend said that if I was still up working into the wee hours I should take a break and turn on the telly. Rushmore would be on and although she hadn't seen it, she'd heard it got great reviews.I kept working and forgot the time. The telly was on but I ignored it. All of a sudden I began hearing this very weird dialog. 'We like the same things - soup, snow peas, talking - and not talking.' I thought to myself 'what is this - some kind of weird porn movie?' And I continued ignoring it for a while longer until I heard the voices of Levy and Begley Jr. It was then I remembered what the girlfriend had said.I looked the movie up at the IMDb quickly and was surprised to see who was behind it: Bill Murray and company and the man with the extra loud guitar amplifier. I knew then I was lucky to still be awake to witness this one.I made two more checks at the IMDb before getting back to the movie: the number of awards and nominations and the box office. Not surprisingly this was a low budget venture, and not surprisingly either it's garnered tonnes of awards and nominations. The studio made a profit off this one, but it's pocket change in comparison to the big blockbusters. Still, it must be a kind of Woody Allen and Orion kind of thing: movies like this make the studio look good.

Review title: tragic, hilarious, subtle, and powerful..... all at once
Review_body: If you are looking for convention, don't see this movie. This movie isn't a happy story. Although you could say this movie has a happy ending, if you have a smile at the end of the film, you're missing something.The characters are all disturbed on some level; Max, although giving the appearance of a mature young boy, really knows very little about life. Herman has the money and the house - but his kids are brats and his life is going nowhere. Rosemary is in love with the perfect man... but he is dead. Yes, this movie is funny, but I mean it when I say throughout the film I was on the verge of either bursting into laughter or tears.The movie is funny because it's true. The movie is sad because it's true. What you expect to happen and what you hope happen never really happen, because really this movie is about life. If you're the type of person who can see the humor and sadness in everyday life, you'll love this movie. It may not be uplifting, but it is reassuring. These characters - with what little they have - learn to be happier people. They learn to move on.Wes Anderson made a story that can encompass all these emotions in a relatively simply plot. Don't be fooled; a lot is going on here. Issues of love, social class, morality, and convention are all brought up. It will make you think about what kind of world you live in, and what kind of a person you are.10/10

a few years ago, when royal tenenbaums came out, I read a review about it and became curious. I was happy to get this flick at a flea market and watched it with my friend and- it was awful.. how could anyone give money to produce such a bad, unspectacular piece of boredom. I read a line on the tape, it said: one of the best movies of the year. when u got a slight hope that something will happen or the movie will get better, you sure will be disappointed and its getting worse. in one scene, when Murray wants to jump into the pool, my face moved a bit into a smile, but it was faster gone than it came. please don't take my comment as a hate letter to Anderson, I really liked tenenbaums, and co-writer Wilson is one of my top movie-comedians but Rushmore is so bad, i'd rather watch pearl harbor again than this one. if this is your humor you are either dead or really boring . its not that i don't like boring people, but I don't like boring movies. there's nothing about this one at all.

Greatest teen film ever. I've seen this movie a dozen times and I always find something new in it. This movie talks about all of the things that happens in your average teen aged life. Such as being embarrassed by your family, a crush on someone you have no chance with. Acceptance and rejections. Only its funny when it happens to Max Fischer, a pompous arrogant flunky attending a Prep School (Rushmore). Max then makes friends with Herman Blume, an entrepreneur who is going through his mid-life crisis and is miserable with his family. You watch how Max deals with expulsion from Rushmore and the "betrayel" from Blume. You need to have some intelligence to enjoy this movie, which also applies to all current Wes Anderson films which is what makes this movie truly more of a treasure than some flick at the box office.
This is so bad, it is waste of time watching it. Not funny at all, and it's doesn't make any sense. I'm never gonna watch this movie again.

Rushmore is a brilliantly manipulated exercise in calculated comedy. The actors unique portrayals of their unforgettable characters are superb in the decay that the characters are content with. Wes Anderson truly shines here, this is a piece of cinematic history, and it will be remembered for years to come. It is the best coming of age film, out ranking both The Graduate and Y Tu Mama Tambien. Rushmore has everything that a movie should have; laughter, heartbreak, love, tears, and empathy. I highly recommend this to anyone who hasn't seen it. Rushmore is quite amazing in its simplicity. It glorifies the world that it propels itself into at full force.

Review title: When A man makes a great movie he has no right to keep it to himself
Review_body: Hands down the best film I've ever seen. Everything in this movie is executed perfectly, Bill Murray is brilliant dead pan and Jason Schwartzman is absolutely fantastic at being the angsty but lovable smart-ass. I think any movie that ends with the awesome main character getting the cute Asian girl is grade A material.You just can't find any better writing in a film, even Brian Cox who has but a small supporting role is brilliant. Everyone in this film comes together perfectly and plays their part. I don't see how anyone could not enjoy this film, you'd have to be an old fart not to get it. This is a movie for my generation. Napolean Dynamite stole so much from the characters in this movie. It just shows how powerful Wes Anderson's creation is.

rarely do I ever give a film a 10, but if I own it on DVD, which I own 2 different Rushmore DVDs, it has to be in the 8-10 range. This is one of those movies that no matter how many times you've seen it, if a friend comes over and it happens to be mentioned that he or she didn't, the movie is going in the DVD player.I like most all of wes anderson's stuff, but Rushmore is at the top of the heap in my opinion. They all have the same quirky humor (and most have bill murray too), so if you don't like one, you probably won't like another. But if you do like one, you'll like them all, and there are plenty.Bottom line, rent it, buy it, whatever, if you haven't seen it, see it somehow.

Review title: Max Fischer, a brave attempt to challenge the adult world
Review_body:
The pride, self-righteousness and unpractical ambitions of a teenager was well-captured. Max Ficsher always tries to behave and talk like an adult. On the other hand, Herman who is actually experiencing the mid-life crisis sometimes behaves like a teenager. The fascinating aspect of Wes Anderson film is that you cannot find absolute definition for characters. His characters are of great complexity, and are perfect examples of the 'anti-gravity' parts of the human nature. And because of this, his behaviour, although seems absurd, but also shows his positive side: a young man trying to find acceptance and win respect, in spite of failing to get good grades. The definition of success is challenged by him.
Dramatic plots, polemic-style lines and the sad, embarrassing moments of the characters together compose this comedy-drama. When watching it, there are many hilarious moments, but a deeper sense of the frustrating obstacles also responds the viewers as we all experienced those emotional fluctuations. The embarrassing emotions and thoughts as a teenager are not a dreadful thing to avoid, but the treasure of the complex human nature.

Review title: I GOT My Money Back, Pity I Couldn't Get The Time
Review_body: This is the most awful movie I have ever had the misfortune to see.  It is also one of the few movies I have ever walked out on and asked for a refund. I actually left a group of friends sitting in the theater because I couldn't stand any more of the antics of Max Fischer and crew.  The theater didn't ask any questions, and returned my money promptly.  I hope never to have to endure another such movie in my lifetime.

Review title: Good double feature with "Ferris Bueller's Day Off"
Review_body: Next time my brother and sister and I and maybe some of our high school friends are all at my Dad's house I am going to propose a Ferris Bueller/Rushmore double feature viewing.  They complement each other well. Boy, I am glad I am done with high school.  Maybe I'll start a backgammon club, though.

Rarely do we see such a brave and honest effort as Rushmore. Although the trailers and commercials are touting this film as a zany, off beat comedy, it is immensely more. What Wes Anderson has created is a film, that is true and from the heart.  What Anderson gives us in Rushmore is not only Bill Murray's finest performance, which he will boldly admit to, but a film that in 20 years will be looked back upon as a crisp coming of age story that is on the top a wicked comedy and at times a very somber look at growth.  Sure adolescence has been done before but not with such a gifted filmmaker at the helm. So on the day that Rushmore comes to your town do yourself an enormous favor and watch it, with ease.  Let this marvelous creation take you over like many have done.  You won't regret it.

Rushmore is probably the most unique film I've ever seen. It has a pace that's highly uncommon for a comedy, it's leisurely but never quick. Rushmore has deep, pensive moments, and it also has sequences that are downright giddy in their pleasant demeanors. A character like Herman Blume (Bill Murray), probably in his late 40's, speaks with the same amount of respect to our protagonist Max's young chapel partner Dirk, a boy no older than twelve. And with all of the respect that each of the characters has for the others, you'd hardly expect that Max would be such a hard boy to like. He's selfish, cunning, and occasionally downright mean. But what keeps us from hating Max is that all of his actions are driven by love. Love for his school and love for Rosemary Cross (Olivia Williams), a first grade teacher at Rushmore Academy. As Max's relationships with both Miss Cross and Mr. Blume evolve, those two eventually fall for each other, sending Max into a kind of downward spiral that tests his lust for life and all of his friendships. Few dramas (let alone comedies) have the depth and power that every scene in Rushmore seems to give off like a scent.

Review title: projection, youthful ignorance in emotional display
Review_body: the degree to which i project emotionally onto this movie is unsurpassed. to me, rushmore is a burnished marriage of grit and heroism; something in rushmore's totality cuts deep into me, nineteen.
I laughed so hard, I was crying!  Haven't had that happen in years.  Very creative, great performances, and extremely quirky- Brilliant!!!

Review title: Bill Murray's Best Performance Since Groundhog Day!!
Review_body: Bill Murray's back!!!  Rushmore is fantastic!!!  A film that gives you a lot of thinking!!!

Review title: Ferris Bueller meets Something About Mary--No sparks
Review_body: This film is flat and uneven.  It started out with plot potential, but the editing was horrible to the point of distraction.  I guess you could call it "Something About Ferris"--but that wouldn't do justice to either of those wonderful films this movie copies from.  I gave it a "4" because there were some clever moments, albeit too few and far between.

Let me begin by saying that Bottle Rocket is one of my favorite films ever. And in Rushmore, Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson have again managed to create some of the best and most intriguing characters found onscreen today.  Their affection for a heightened sense of the bizarre serves as terrific gryst for the comedic mill and carries audiences through some of the slower parts of the film.  Bill Murray's hilarious yet subtle performance is truly deserving of all the praise it's received, making him a likely contender come Oscar time.  Despite the fact that it is a Disney film, Rushmore's dark, quirky sense of humor and unorthodox storyline give it a feel true to Anderson's indie roots.  I only hope that these filmmakers can keep their vision and creative integrity in tact despite all the attention being lavished on them because we need more movies like this.

How is it this movie went directly to theatre and not to home video? While the humor had its upbringing moments, the overall plot and moral of the story was beyond me. Absolutely no climax or any trace of a story could be found in this film. People who got a kick out of movies like "Angus" and "Dumb and Dumber" will probably like this. Also, another unfortunate element to add is the horrific display of acting by Bill Murray. This has to be his most atrocious film out of his brilliant career and hopefully he will not continue in this path.
This was the best movie I have seen in years.  Funny and insightful with a great performance by Bill Murray.  I haven't laughed out loud in a movie theater for a long time.

I rented this film with high hopes.  As a teacher of film, I am constantly looking for new material to show my students.  This flick will NOT be one of them.  Although the actors put forth a fine effort (Bill Murray especially) they didn't have a script meaty enough to support their talent.  I kept waiting for something to happen.  The loose plot line and dweeby dialog (let me tell you no real high school student talks like that) made me wish for interactive video so that I could yell at these people to get a life.
